conversion of CO2 to DME. Diagram 1 Fig. 1 CO2 conversion and product yields for CO, oxygenated HCs (CH3OH + DME), CH3OH, and DME for different catalyst configurations: (1) CuZnZr ( Image 1 ); (2) (CuZnZr > FER) with CuZnZr ( Image 1 ) upstream of FER ( Image 2 ) as two separate beds; (3) (CuZnZr on FER, <1 µm) ( Image 3 ) bifunctional catalysts. SiC ( Image 4 ) was added as a diluent to improve heat transfer. The reactions was carried out at 240 ℃, 25 bar with a feed of CO2:H2:N2 = 3:9:1 (in moles) at a flow rate of 15.6 L (STP) • h−1. The catalyst loadings were 0.883 g each of CuZnZr and FER (when it was included). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Comparison of bifunctional (CuZnZr + FER) catalysts with different proximity: (2 A) (CuZnZr on FER, <1 µm) was with CuZnZr nanoparticles deposited on < 1 µm FER zeolite; (2B) (CuZnZr + FER, <10 µm) was a physical mixture of CuZnZr and FER powders before palletization; (2 C) (CuZnZr + FER, >250 µm) was a physical mixture of separately pelletized (250–500 µm) CuZnZr and FER samples. The reactions were carried out at 25 bar with a feed of CO2:H2:N2 = 3:9:1 (in moles) at a flow rate of 15.6 L (STP) • h−1. The catalyst loadings were 0.883 g each of CuZnZr and FER. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Comparison of the catalytic performance of CuZnZr single component (3 A) and bifunctional catalysts ((CuZnZr + FER) and (CuZnZr || FER)) (3B) either as pellets (250–500 µm) in a packed-bed reactor or as a coated monolith. The reactions were carried out at 25 bar with a feed of CO2:H2:N2 = 3:9:1 (in moles) at a flow rate of 15.6 L (STP) • h−1. The catalyst loadings were identical within 3 A or 3B; all had about 0.883 g CuZnZr and FER (for 3B). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Effect of GHSV on the catalytic performance of a layer structured (CuZnZr || FER) bifunctional monolith catalyst (4 A) and kinetic analysis of the same activity data (4B). The reactions were carried out at 240 ℃ and 25 bar with a feed of CO2:H2:N2 = 3:9:1 (in moles). The feed gas flow rates were increased from 15.6 to 78.0 L (STP) • h−1 while the volume of the monolith catalyst was kept the same. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 On-stream durability testing of a layer structured (CuZnZr || FER) bifunctional monolith catalyst. The reactions were carried out at 240 ℃ and 25 bar with a feed of CO2:H2:N2 = 3:9:1 (in moles). The GHSV was set at 2156 h−1 in the first 53 h. It was subsequently increased to 5390 h−1 thereafter. Layer structured bifunctional monolith catalysts for energy-efficient conversion of CO2 to dimethyl ether Hai-Ying Chen 1 ⁎ Josh Pihl Todd J. Toops Sreshtha Sinha Majumdar National Transportation Research Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, 2360 Cherahala Blvd, Knoxville, TN 37932, USA National Transportation Research Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory 2360 Cherahala Blvd Knoxville TN 37932 USA National Transportation Research Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, 2360 Cherahala Blvd, Knoxville, TN 37932, USA ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 orcid.org/0000–0003-4116–2607 A monolith supported bifunctional catalyst for the direct conversion of CO2 to dimethyl ether was developed and evaluated. The catalyst consists of a layer structured configuration, in which a CuO/ZnO/ZrO2 component for methanol synthesis using CO2 as feedstock and a Ferrierite zeolite component for the subsequent dehydration reaction are washcoated onto the channel surfaces of a metallic monolith substrate as two consecutive layers. The metal substrate provides heat conduction to regulate the catalyst bed temperature. The layered configuration significantly improves the synergistic effects of the two components, resulting in a 20% increase in the productivity for dimethyl ether at 240 ℃ as compared with the conventional catalysts with the two components being blended in various levels of proximity. Additionally, the layer structured design minimizes the undesirable interaction between the two components and drastically improves the on-stream durability of the catalyst. No activity decline was observed in a 146-h performance test. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CO2 conversion Monolith catalyst Layer structured configuration Synergistic effect Catalyst durability Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Transformation of mobility technologies to reach net zero CO2 emissions is crucial in meeting global goals for carbon neutrality by the middle of the century as the transportation sector currently emits roughly 30% of the greenhouse gas emissions that contribute to climate change [1]. While light-duty passenger vehicles and medium-duty trucks can be electrified, certain parts of the transportation sector, such as aviation, maritime, and off-road heavy machinery, will still rely on liquid fuels in the foreseeable future to meet the demand for high energy density [2]. Converting CO2, either from point sources or through direct air capture, to liquid fuels with renewable energy and green hydrogen can be a workable path to accelerate the decarbonization of the transportation sector [3]. CO2 can be hydrogenated to a wide range of fuels or chemicals depending on the catalytic processes chosen. Among the processes, conversion of CO2 to dimethyl ether (DME) is of great interest [4–8]. It preserves the highest amount of chemical energy of H2, and the chemical reactions can be carried out under moderate pressure (∼20–50 bar) and temperature (∼200–300 ℃), making it more energy efficient [9,10]. DME is a non-toxic clean fuel with physical properties similar to that of liquid petroleum gas (LPG), so it can be transported through the established LPG storage and distribution infrastructure [4]. It has a high cetane number (>55) and can be used as a substitute for diesel fuel for heavy-duty diesel engines [4,5]. It is also a versatile chemical intermediate for production of widely used chemicals and can serve as a H2 carrier [6]. The current commonly-used industrial process for DME production utilizes syngas (a mixture of H2, CO, and a low level of CO2) as the feedstock and involves two distinct catalytic reaction steps [7,8,11,12]. First, syngas is converted into methanol over metal oxide catalysts, typically CuO/ZnO/Al2O3: (R1) C O + 2 H 2 ⇌ C H 3 O H ⁢ Δ H ° = − 90 ⋅ 6 k J / m o l (R2) C O + 3 H 2 ⇌ C H 3 O H + H O 2 ⁢ Δ H ° = − 49 ⋅ 4 k J / m o l The produced methanol is subsequently dehydrated in a separate reactor to DME over acid catalysts, such as γ-Al2O3 or zeolites: (R3) 2 ⁢ C H 3 O H ⇌ C H 3 O C H 3 + H 2 O Δ H ° = − 23 ⋅ 4 k J / m o l Combining (R2) and (R3) results in a global reaction for the conversion of CO2 to DME: (R4) 2 ⁢ C O 2 + 6 H 2 ⇌ C H 3 O C H 3 + 3 H 2 O Δ H ° = − 122 ⋅ 2 k J / m o l With CO2 as feedstock, however, the more practical approach is to add an additional step into the process to facilitate the reverse water gas shift reaction: (R5) ⁢ C O 2 + H 2 ⇌ C O + H 2 O Δ H ° = 41 ⋅ 2 k J / m o l Water formed in this step is removed before CO is fed to the methanol synthesis step (R1). This improves methanol yield as compared with direct hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol (R2) [12]. A main reason for carrying out these reactions in separate reactors is that each of the catalytic processes can be optimized to achieve the highest efficiency of material conversion [7,12]. To maximize the overall energy conversion efficiency, these reactors are typically located at a centralized chemical plant. This arrangement requires great capital investment and intense energy supply but provides economies of scale [11,12]. This approach is not compatible with most renewable energy sources as those are generally decentralized and have intermittent availability. To effectively convert renewable energy into storable chemical energy and to reduce capital and operational costs, it is highly desirable to combine different chemical processes into one integrated modular system. CO2 can be directly converted to DME in a single reactor, but this will require bifunctional catalysts that contain both metal oxides, such as CuO/ZnO/ZrO2, to catalyze methanol synthesis (R2) and acid components, such as zeolites, for the dehydration step (R3) to complete the two reactions in tandem. Combining the two catalytic components into one system also creates synergies as the in-situ consumption of methanol in (R3) forces (R2) forwards to achieve thermodynamic equilibrium, thus improving one-pass CO2 conversion and energy utilization efficiency [4,7,12–16]. A considerable amount of research effort has been devoted to the development of suitable bifunctional catalysts for the direct synthesis of DME using CO2 as feedstock, but several main challenges remain to be overcome [16–18]. As the CO2 hydrogenation reaction (R2) is exothermic and leads to a volume reduction, low reaction temperature (<300 ℃) and high pressure (∼20–50 bar) drive the equilibrium toward CO2 conversion. On the other hand, higher temperature can improve the reaction kinetics. To balance the two aspects for a maximum DME yield, the catalyst operating temperature window is generally very narrow. Although the widely studied Cu-based methanol synthesis catalysts, such as CuO/ZnO/ZrO2, do exhibit excellent activities at around 240–260 ℃, the catalysts can suffer from rapid deactivation at temperatures above 300 ℃ due to Cu sintering [18,19]. To improve heat transfer and to avoid hot spot formation on the catalysts typically encountered with pelletized catalysts in packed-bed reactors, micro-channel reactors, monolithic reactors, and highly conductive structured catalytic reactors have been explored [20–25]. These designs demonstrated remarkably improved on-stream durability but have not attracted enough attention mainly because of the relatively low space time yield of these systems compared with a packed-bed reactor design. Therefore, these concepts have not been proven in a large-scale reactor. To maximize the synergistic effects, it is desirable to place the metal oxides near the acid components [26,27]. When the two components are in close contact with each other, however, detrimental interactions may occur, which hurts the long-term durability of the catalysts [28–31]. For example, Bonura et al. reported that a bifunctional catalyst with CuO/ZnO/ZrO2 intimately mixed with a Ferrierite zeolite exhibited superior activity for the direct conversion of CO2 to DME, but also noted that the catalyst progressively lost its CO2 hydrogenation activity as well as its selectivity to DME in a 150-h durability test [32–34]. Migration of Cu to the zeolite component was identified as one of main deactivation mechanisms [34]. To circumvent this issue, bifunctional catalysts with a core-shell structure were explored [30,35–38]. Typically, the acid component is placed on the shell covering the metal oxides core. Thus, methanol formed in the core must diffuse through the shell, where it is dehydrated to DME. Because the interaction of the two components is limited to the interfacial region, core-shell catalysts do show better on-stream durability than the conventional catalysts with the two components simply mixed with each other; however, deactivation is still noticeable. Also, preparation of catalysts with a core-shell structure and good mechanical strength is nontrivial. It typically requires additional binding materials and dense packing of the components, which often reduces the gas diffusivity to the catalytic components. As a result, both experimental results and model simulation showed that catalysts with a core-shell structure are generally less effective [13,39]. In this study, we report a layer structured monolith catalyst design that overcomes the challenges mentioned above. The catalytic activity and selectivity of the new configuration were compared against the conventional pelletized bifunctional catalysts in a packed-bed reactor. The results clearly demonstrated the performance advantages of the new design. More remarkably, 146-h on-stream durability testing demonstrated excellent stability of the layer structured monolith catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalytic components selection and preparation CuO/ZnO/ZrO2 (CuZnZr) was selected as the methanol synthesis catalytic component as it exhibits better activity and stability than the commercial CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst for methanol synthesis with CO2 as feedstock (R2) [40–45]. The specific composition, CuO:ZnO:ZrO2 = 6:3:1 (in moles), used in the this study was based on the work reported by Bonura et al [32–34,40,46]. The sample was prepared by a gel-oxalate coprecipitation method [46,47]. Nitrate salts of Cu, Zn and Zr were dissolved in ethanol to form a 0.1 M (as the total metal ions) mixture solution. A separately prepared oxalic acid solution in ethanol (1 M) was added dropwise to the above metal mixture solution under vigorous stirring until the quantity of oxalic acid reached 120% of the stoichiometric amount of the total metal ions. After mixing overnight, the precipitate was filtered, dried at 110 ℃, then calcined at 360 ℃ for 4 h. XRD (Fig. S1 of the Supplementary Information) and SEM (Fig. S2A of the Supplementary Information) analyses confirmed that the calcined samples were mixtures of CuO and ZnO nanoparticles with a primary particle size in the range of ∼20–30 nm. The powder sample was either used directly as a CuZnZr component to prepare other CuZnZr containing catalysts or pelletized and sieved to 250–500 µm particles as catalysts. Zeolites, owing to their hydrophobicity, are more suitable than the more commonly studied γ-Al2O3 as a solid acid for the subsequent dehydration of methanol to DME in the process with CO2 as feedstock because H2O is generated in both steps (R2 and R3) and zeolites are more tolerant to high concentration of steam than γ-Al2O3 [32,48,49]. A wide range of zeolites with various framework structures and different Si/Al ratio have been evaluated. Ferrierite zeolites with Si/Al ratios around 10 were reported to exhibit the highest activity and on-stream stability because of the unique 10-membered ring framework structure and the balanced acidity and hydrophobicity properties [32,43,48–52]. In this study, NH4 +-form Ferrierite zeolite with a Si/Al = 10 and a primary crystal size less than 1 µm was obtained from Zeolyst International. The BET surface area of the sample was reported to be 400 m2/g. The sample was calcined at 550 ℃ for 4 h to H+-form Ferrierite (FER). 2.2 Pelletized bifunctional catalyst preparation A conventional bifunctional catalyst (CuZnZr on FER, < 1 µm) was prepared in a similar way as the CuZnZr catalyst, except that an equal weight amount of H+-form FER was added into the CuZnZr mixture solution before precipitation. This resulted in direct deposition of CuZnZr nanoparticles on the external surfaces of FER to maximize the direct contact between the two components. XRD (Fig. S1 of the Supplementary Information) and SEM (Fig. S2B of the Supplementary Information) analyses confirm the catalyst configuration, and that the proximity of the two components is less than 1 µm. A second conventional bifunctional catalyst (CuZnZr + FER, < 10 µm) was prepared by mixing equal weight amounts of the CuZnZr and FER powders by mortar and pestle for 30 min to achieve a uniform powder mixture with the two components in the proximity of less than 10 µm (see Fig. S1 for the XRD result and Fig. S2C for the SEM result of the Supplementary Information). Both the (CuZnZr on FER, <1 µm) and the (CuZnZr + FER, < 10 µm) powders were pelletized and sieved to 250–500 µm particles. A third conventional bifunctional catalyst (CuZnZr + FER, >250 µm) was prepared by physically mixing the separately pelletized CuZnZr and FER particles (both in the range of 250–500 µm) together at a 1:1 wt ratio. 2.3 Layer structured monolith catalyst design concept and preparation A schematic of the layer structured monolith catalysts developed in this study is shown in Diagram 1. In this design, a metallic monolith substrate is utilized both as a support for catalyst coatings and as a heat conductive medium to regulate the catalyst temperature. A thin layer of methanol synthesis catalyst, such as CuO/ZnO/ZrO2, is coated directly on the channel surfaces of the metal monolith substrate. This facilitates heat transfer between the methanol synthesis catalyst and the metal foil and eliminates hot spot formation that can cause catalyst deactivation. It also enables uniform temperature control throughout the reactor. A second layer of acid component, such as Ferrierite zeolite, for the dehydration reaction (R3) is subsequently applied on top of the methanol synthesis catalyst. Such a layered structure, as in a core-shell catalyst configuration, ensures that methanol formed in the bottom layer must diffuse through the dehydration catalyst before it reaches the gas phase and exits the reactor. It also limits the direct contact of the metal oxides and the zeolite components to the interfacial region and minimizes the potential detrimental interactions between the two components as compared with the cases in which the two components are intimately mixed as less than about 20–40 µm particles. Different from core-shell designs, catalyst coatings on monolith substrates can be highly porous as long as the coatings are adequately adhered to the substrate because the mechanical strength of the element is defined by the substrates not the catalyst coatings. Also, the thickness of the catalyst coating for each component can be adjusted independently and in a much wider range compared with core-shell designs [13,53]. These features can be advantageous in enhancing catalyst utilization efficiency while offering flexibility to adjust product distribution [54]. FeCr-alloy metallic monolith substrate was used in this study. Cores with a dimension of 19 mm in diameter and 51 mm in length, 600 cells per square inch (CPSI), and 0.05 mm wall thickness were purchased from Performance Industries. CuZnZr monolith catalysts were prepared by blending the CuZnZr catalyst power with 5% ZrO2 (added as zirconium acetate) to form a consistent slurry, which was subsequently washcoated onto metal monolith cores. Layer structured (CuZnZr || FER) bifunctional monolith catalysts were prepared by applying a second layer of slurry made of FER and 5% ZrO2 onto the CuZnZr monolith catalysts prepared above. The target catalyst loadings were 61 g (CuZnZr + ZrO2) • L−1 plus 61 g (FER + ZrO2) • L−1 when added, with respect to the monolith substrate volume. Accordingly, each CuZnZr monolith core sample contains about 0.883 g of CuZnZr and each (CuZnZr || FER) bifunctional monolith core sample has additional 0.883 g of FER component. The quantities of the catalytic components on each monolith catalysts are about the same as the corresponding pelletized catalyst in a packed-bed configuration (see below). The monolith catalysts were dried and calcined at 360 ℃ for 4 h after each coating step. 2.4 Catalytic activity evaluation Catalytic activity evaluation was carried out on a flow reactor at a pressure of 25 bar with a feed gas mixture of CO2:H2:N2 = 3:9:1 (in moles). All the gases (99.995% CO2, UHP H2, and UHP N2) were from Airgas. These gases were controlled by the corresponding mass flow controllers to achieve a total flow of 15.6 L (STP) • h−1. For pelletized catalysts, 0.883 g of CuZnZr (and 0.883 g FER when it was included) as 250–500 µm particles were first mixed with SiC grits with a particle size about 365 µm at a weight ratio of 1:5. The mixture was loaded into a quartz tube (16 mm inner diameter and 19 mm outer diameter) with a frit as a packed-bed configuration, which was then wrapped with a layer of fiberglass mat and inserted into the stainless steel flow reactor tube with a 25 mm inner diameter. For monolith catalysts, core samples were wrapped and loaded directly into the stainless steel flow reactor tube. A thermocouple was placed 10 mm in front of the catalyst to control the catalyst inlet temperature. The stainless steel reactor tube was heat by two Thermo Scientific/Lindberg Blue tube furnaces in series. The outlet gas lines were heated to 150 ℃ to prevent product condensation. Before the catalytic activity evaluation, the catalysts were pretreated in the reactor at 300 ℃ for 2 h in a gas mixture of 5% H2 in N2 with a flow rate of 15.6 L (STP) • h−1 at 1 bar. The reduced catalyst was cooled to the reaction temperatures (e.g. 240 ℃) and the full feed gas was introduced. After stabilization for 1 h at each temperature, gas products were analyzed by an on-line GC (SRI Instruments, Multiple Gas #5) and a gas phase Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectrometer (MKS Instruments, Model 2030HS). The GC was used to identify products and the gas phase FTIR was used to quantify CO, CH3OH, and DME. In this study, the product yield is calculated based on the moles of carbon in the product. Hence 1 mol of DME molecules would be counted as 2 moles of C1 product. This makes it easier to verify mass balance. With the catalysts and evaluation conditions used in this study, CO, CH3OH and DME were the only detectable C-containing products besides CO2 in the feed gas. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Evaluation of pelletized catalysts in a packed-bed configuration First, we assessed the catalytic performance of the catalytic components and a conventional bifunctional catalyst as pelletized particles (250–500 µm) in a packed-bed configuration for the direct conversion of CO2 to DME. Fig. 1 summarizes the CO2 conversion and the product yields for CO, CH3OH, DME and oxygenated hydrocarbons (CH3OH + DME) at 240 ℃ for CuZnZr only, CuZnZr followed by FER as two separate catalyst beds (CuZnZr > FER), and the bifunctional catalyst with CuZnZr directly deposited on FER (CuZnZr on FER, <1 µm). At 240 ℃, all the catalysts reached the peak conversions for oxygenated hydrocarbons (HCs). By itself, CuZnZr catalyst achieves 15.9% CO2 conversion, with CH3OH as the only oxygenated HC product at a yield of 4.8%. Simply placing an equal amount of FER component downstream of the CuZnZr catalyst as two separate catalyst beds (CuZnZr > FER) has no effect on CO2 conversion or the yield of total oxygenated HCs. The FER catalyst converts about 70% of the methanol produced by the upstream CuZnZr catalyst to DME, resulting in a simple additive effect. In contrast, the bifunctional catalyst (CuZnZr on FER, <1 µm), with the compositions identical to those of the CuZnZr > FER but with nanoparticles of CuZnZr directly deposited on the external surfaces of < 1 µm FER particles to achieve close contact, shows an increase of CO2 conversion to 16.6%. The yield for the total oxygenated HCs (counted as C1) increased to 6.3% and the selectivity for DME also increased slightly (to 73%). These results reaffirm the advantages of bifunctional catalysts for the direct conversion of CO2 to DME. The results shown in Fig. 1 agree well with what has been reported in the literature taking into consideration that slightly different reactions conditions were used in different research groups [33,34]. In the literature reports, however, there were conflicting results on how closely the metal oxides and the acid components must be oriented to maximize the synergistic effects [55,56]. To assess if different levels of the proximity between the CuZnZr and FER components affects the performance of the bifunctional catalysts, two additional pelletized catalysts with identical compositions as the (CuZnZr on FER, <1 µm) catalyst but with gradually increased grain sizes of the individual components were evaluated. The (CuZnZr + FER, <10 µm) catalyst, prepared by mixing separately prepared CuZnZr and FER power samples in mortar and pestle to form a uniform powder mixture before it was pelletized into 250–500 µm particles, has grain sizes of each individual component less than 10 µm. The third (CuZnZr + FER, >250 µm), a physical mixture of CuZnZr and FER pellets, has grain sizes of each individual pellet in the range of 250–500 µm. Fig. 2A-2 C compare the CO2 conversion and the product yields of CO, CH3OH, and DME in the temperature region of 200–280 ℃ for the three pelletized bifunctional catalysts. All show almost identical performance. The results demonstrate that, with the two components used in this study, mixing the two components with individual grain sizes in the range of ∼1–500 µm can achieve the same level of synergistic effects as directly depositing CuZnZr nanoparticles onto FER zeolite. This suggests that, with this system, gas phase methanol is the only intermediate and the direct conversion of CO2 to DME proceeds through (R2) and (R3) in tandem. Otherwise, if other surface intermediates are involved in the reactions, one would expect the performance of the catalysts to change by varying the level of proximity of the two components. Therefore, the results also point out that it is possible to realize the synergistic effects through different configurations of the two components while minimizing their detrimental interactions that can lead to catalyst long-term durability issues. 3.2 Comparison of monolith catalysts versus pelletized catalysts As a different type of configuration, the same CuZnZr and FER components were washcoated onto 600 CPSI metallic monolith substrates either as a single layered structure (for CuZnZr) or as a double layered structure (for CuZnZr || FER). The catalyst loadings were targeted at 61 g • L−1 each for the CuZnZr and the FER components, which roughly corresponded to 20 µm average coating thickness for the CuZnZr and 30 µm for the FER component. It is worth noting that the coating process was not fully optimized in this study. With process optimization, the catalyst loading/thickness can be increased by a factor of 2–3 [53]. The addition of 5% ZrO2 binding material and the following coating process to apply the CuZnZr and FER components onto monolith substrates do not alter the fundamental catalytic properties of the components but do affect how the two components interact with each other. CO, CH3OH, and DME (when the FER catalyst is present) remain as the only detectable reaction products. For clarity and a fair comparison, we use productivity, defined as millimoles of oxygenated HC products (counted as C1) formed per gram of the CuZnZr component in the catalyst over a given time (per h), to compare the catalytic performance of the catalysts tested either as pellets in a packed-bed configuration or as coatings on a monolithic substrate. Fig. 3A compares the productivities of CH3OH and CO as a function of the catalyst inlet temperature for the pelletized and the metal monolith supported CuZnZr catalysts. Both catalysts showed nearly identical productivity for CH3OH in the temperature region of 200–280 ℃. This is not surprising and confirms that our coating process does not alter the catalytic function of the CuZnZr component. The CO productivity for the monolith catalyst was slightly higher than that for the pelletized catalyst at temperatures above 240 ℃. This could be due to the contribution from the FeCr metal substrate. Nevertheless, the contribution is negligible at 240 ℃ at which the catalyst reaches the peak CH3OH productivity. Interestingly, significant improvements in productivities for DME, CH3OH, and CO are observed for the layer structured (CuZnZr || FER) monolith catalyst with the CuZnZr component in the bottom layer and the FER component in the top layer as compared with a conventional bifunctional catalyst made by mixing the two components as pellets (see Fig. 3B). At 240 ℃, where DME reaches its peak yield for both catalysts, the DME productivity increases by 20% from 8.5 to 10.2 (mmol C1 • g−1 CuZnZr • h−1). The productivity for CH3OH also increases by a similar percentage (27%) from 3.0 to 3.8 (mmol C1 • g−1 CuZnZr • h−1). As demonstrated by the results in Fig. 2, mixing the CuZnZr and FER components at different levels of proximity resulted in the same level of synergetic effects. The additional performance enhancement observed in Fig. 3B for the monolith catalyst could be attributed to two factors: (1) more uniform temperature distribution within the metallic monolith catalyst and (2) the layer structured configuration. Since a considerable amount of SiC diluent was used in the packed-bed configuration and the diameter of the packed-bed tube is relatively small (ID = 16 mm), we believe that the temperature distribution in the packed-bed reactor was reasonably uniform as well although we made no attempt to measure the temperature gradient within the catalyst bed because of the technical difficulties in inserting thermocouples into the catalyst bed in a pressurized reactor. Additionally, the results in Fig. 3A also indicate that the overall temperature profiles for the two configurations are comparable as both the pelletized and the monolith supported CuZnZr catalysts achieve nearly identical catalytic performance. Furthermore, the data in Fig. 3B show that the productivities for DME and CH3OH from the bifunctional catalysts in either the monolithic or packed-bed configuration is relatively insensitive to temperature variation around 240–260 ℃. All these results suggest that more uniform temperature distribution for the monolith catalyst is not the major factor although it may have some contributions to the catalytic performance enhancement. As illustrated in Diagram 1, with the layer structured configuration of the monolith catalyst, CO2 and H2 in the feed gas would first diffuse through the top FER layer to reach the bottom CuZnZr catalyst, where they are converted to CH3OH and H2O (R2). Because the catalyst coatings are porous there is no diffusion barrier for CO2 and H2 to reach the CuZnZr catalyst. In the subsequent step, the produced CH3OH (and H2O) would have to pass through the FER layer before it enters the gas phase in the channels and exits the reactor. Thus, the layered catalyst structure ensures all CH3OH molecules formed have opportunities to react on the zeolite catalyst. Additionally, for the CH3OH molecules that do not react and find their way to reach the gas phase in the monolith channel, if these molecules diffuse back to the catalyst, they will have to pass through the zeolite layer again before reaching the CuZnZr layer. This provides a second opportunity for the CH3OH to be converted to DME. Therefore, it is likely that the CH3OH concentration in the bottom CuZnZr layer of the monolith catalyst is lower than that for the pelletized catalyst in which the CuZnZr component is exposed directly to the gas phase. A lower concentration of CH3OH on the surface of the CuZnZr component favors (R2) going forward. In addition, with its microporous framework structure and high surface area (0.42 nm x 0.54 nm for the 10-member rings and 0.35 nm x 0.48 nm for the 8-member rings, 400 m2/g BET surface area), FER zeolite in the top layer of the monolith catalyst provides adsorption sites for H2O which drive H2O away from the bottom CuZnZr component. This also favors CH3OH formation reaction (R2), as well as the reverse water gas shift reaction (R5) resulting in a higher CO formation as shown in Fig. 3B. Therefore, the layer structured configuration in the monolith catalyst is more likely to be the major contributing factor that leads to the additional productivity improvement. 3.3 Assessment of monolith catalysts at different space velocities One general concern on the use of monolith catalysts for industrial chemical process applications is that the catalysts may require a large reactor volume because of the void spaces in the monolith channels, which results in a reduced space time yield of the reactor. While space is even more constrained in automotive applications, monolith catalysts are installed on every modern vehicle to abate the toxic pollutants from the engine exhaust. For automotive applications, the open channels of the monolith catalysts are actually beneficial in reducing the pressure drop in the exhaust pipe. The presence of void space for a monolith catalyst is compensated by more effective catalyst utilization because the thin coatings allow more feed gas to flow through the channels and still achieve efficient high conversions. To probe how the bifunctional monolith catalyst responds to the increase of feed gas flux, the gas flow rates were gradually increased by a factor of 5 from 15.6 L• h−1 to 78.0 L• h−1 while the volume of the monolith core sample was kept the same and the reaction temperature was hold at 240 ℃. Accordingly, the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) over the monolith catalyst was increased from 1078 to 5390 h−1. Fig. 4A shows that, although the yields of CO, CH3OH, and DME decrease with the increase of gas flow rates, the reduction is not linear. As a net result, the productivities for the products of DME and CH3OH at a fixed amount (volume) of catalyst increase significantly. For example, the DME productivity increases by a factor of about 3 from 8.7 to 24.3 (mmol C1 • g−1 CuZnZr • h−1) by increasing the feed gas flow rate by a factor of 5. It is worth noting that the reduction in CO yield is more pronounced than that for DME and CH3OH with the increase of gas flow rate. Therefore, increasing the feed gas flux not only improves the productivities for oxygenated HCs but also increases their selectivity. This also implies that the product yield for the direct conversion of CO2 to DME over the monolith catalyst is largely controlled by the thermodynamic equilibrium of the chemical reactions (R2), (R4), and (R5). To better understand the chemical reaction process, an empirical kinetic analysis of the data shown in Fig. 4A is carried out. For this purpose, (R6) is re-written as: (R6) CO2 + 3 H2 ⇌ 1/2 (CH3-O-CH3) + 3/2 H2O The reason of introducing ½ (CH3-O-CH3) is that, in our data analysis, we count 1 mol of DME as 2 moles of C1 product. Therefore, for (R4′), we consider ½ (CH3-O-CH3) as a pseudo-molecule. By treating (R2), (R4′), and (R5) as three independent reactions that follow first order kinetics near their equilibrium points with respect to the concentrations of the feed of CO2 and the products of CO, CH3OH or DME, we can reprocess the data in Fig. 4A as a function of -ln(1-C i /C i∞) versus the residence time (the inverse of GHSV), where, i can be CO, DME (as C1), or CH3OH; C i represents the concentration of each product at a given residence time; and C i∞ represents the concentration of each product at the equilibrium point [57]. The reprocessed data are plotted in Fig. 4B. Each set of data fits well into a straight line that intersects at the origin with a R2 > 0.99. This reaffirms that all three reactions (R2, R4’, and R5) are near their thermodynamic equilibrium points. Because the product yield is largely controlled by the thermodynamic equilibrium, carrying out the reaction at a higher space velocity (or a shorter residence time) to stay away from the equilibrium point favors productivity as demonstrated in Fig. 4A. Under our reaction conditions (25 bar pressure and 240 ℃), the monolith catalyst achieved a productivity of 12.3 mmol C1 of (DME+CH3OH) • g−1 CuZnZr • h−1 at a GHSV of 1078 h−1, which is comparable to what Bonura et al. reported for a conventional bifunctional catalyst under nearly identical conditions except at a higher reaction pressure (30 bar) [33]. Increasing the GHSV by a factor of 5 to 5390 h−1, we increased the oxygenated HCs productivity by a factor ∼ 3 to 36.3 mmol C1 of (DME+CH3OH) • g−1 CuZnZr • h−1. This partially compensates for the lower space volume utilization efficiency associated with monolith catalysts but will lead to more gas recirculation in practical application. More detailed technoeconomic analysis is needed to address the trade-offs. The other approach to increase the space time yield of monolith catalysts is to increase catalyst loadings at a given volume. Coating process optimization could increase the catalyst loading by a factor of ∼2–3 of what was achieved in this study [53]. 3.4 On-stream durability of the bifunctional monolith catalyst The on-stream durability of the bifunctional (CuZnZr || FER) monolith catalyst was evaluated at 240 ℃. The results are summarized in Fig. 5. In the first 53 h of the activity testing, the GHSV was set at 2156 h−1. Thereafter, it was increased to 5390 h−1. During the 146 h of durability testing, the bifunctional monolith catalyst is remarkably stable. No decline in the productivities of DME and CH3OH is observed. There is a small downward trend in CO formation in the first 25 h of testing, but it becomes stable in the rest of the evaluation time. Other small variations for the data points in Fig. 5 were due to test-to-test variabilities in setting up the testing conditions and the analytical equipment. As a comparison, over a conventional bifunctional (CuZnZr on FER) catalyst with nearly identical compositions as our (CuZnZr || FER) monolith catalyst, Bonura et al. reported a steady catalyst deactivation (∼30%) over the course of 100-h evaluation [34]. The remarkable durability results in this study highlight the unique features that monolith substrates can bring into novel catalyst designs for industrial chemical processes: (1) metallic substrates (or other highly conductive materials, such as SiC monolith substrates) improve heat transfer which eliminates hot spot formation that can cause catalyst deactivation; and (2) the channel/wall structure enables complex catalyst designs to not only enhance the desirable synergetic effects but also minimize the detrimental interactions among different catalytic components. The other advantage of using monolith catalysts is that the reactor can be modular in design. Monolith catalysts have been installed on all modern vehicles as modular units in the tailpipe for engine exhaust emission control. The wide adaptation, quick response, and robustness of monolith catalysts have been well established [53]. Such properties can be highly desirable for systems that are designed for CO2 conversion using renewable energy sources as most of these sources are decentralized in remote locations with intermittent surplus capacity. Finally, we want to point it out that, although the application case in this report focuses on the direct conversion of CO2 to DME, the layer structured monolith catalyst concept presented in this study can be applicable to a wide range of other chemical processes that involve tandem chemical reactions. 4 Conclusions A bifunctional monolith catalyst for the direct conversion of CO2 to dimethyl ether has been developed in this study. Different catalytic components, such as CuO/ZnO/ZrO2 for converting CO2 to methanol and Ferrierite zeolite for the subsequent methanol dehydration to dimethyl ether, are washcoated onto a metallic monolith substrate as separated layers. The layer structured configuration enhances the synergistic effects of the two components, resulting in an additional 20% increase in the productivity for dimethyl ether at 240 ℃ as compared with the conventional pelletized catalysts with the two components being blended in various levels of proximity. Another advantage of the layer structured design is that it limits the direct contact between the two components to the interfacial region, thus minimizing their detrimental interactions. This overcomes the durability challenges that most conventional bifunctional catalysts have encountered. Additionally, as the metal foils of the monolith substrate provide good heat conduction, hot spot formation on the monolith catalyst is eliminated. As a result, the monolith catalyst shows outstanding on-stream stability in a 146-h durability test for the direct conversion of CO2 to dimethyl ether. coredata.dc:description: A monolith supported bifunctional catalyst for the direct conversion of CO2 to dimethyl ether was developed and evaluated. The catalyst consists of a layer structured configuration, in which a CuO/ZnO/ZrO2 component for methanol synthesis using CO2 as feedstock and a Ferrierite zeolite component for the subsequent dehydration reaction are washcoated onto the channel surfaces of a metallic monolith substrate as two consecutive layers. The metal substrate provides heat conduction to regulate the catalyst bed temperature. The layered configuration significantly improves the synergistic effects of the two components, resulting in a 20% increase in the productivity for dimethyl ether at 240 ℃ as compared with the conventional catalysts with the two components being blended in various levels of proximity. Additionally, the layer structured design minimizes the undesirable interaction between the two components and drastically improves the on-stream durability of the catalyst. No activity decline was observed in a 146-h performance test.
coredata.dc:title: Layer structured bifunctional monolith catalysts for energy-efficient conversion of CO2 to dimethyl ether
